definition[0]: to rest or do something that is enjoyable, especially after you have been working
example[0]: I just want to sit down and relax.
example[1]: What Robyn needed was a drink to relax her.
example[2]: A hot bath should help to relax you.
definition[1]: to become quiet and calm after you have been upset or nervous, or to make someone do this
example[3]: Once out of danger, he started to relax.
definition[2]: if you relax a part of your body or it relaxes, it becomes less stiff or less tight
example[5]: Gentle exercise can relax stiff shoulder muscles.
definition[3]: to make a rule or law less strict
example[6]: Hughes believes that immigration controls should not be relaxed.
definition[4]: to rest or do something that is enjoyable after you have been working
example[7]: In the evenings, I like to relax with some music and a nice meal.
example[8]: In two weeks’ time I’ll be relaxing on a beach in Greece.
definition[5]: to stop working or stop being active, and sit down or lie down so that you become less tired
example[9]: If you’re tired, we’ll stop and rest for a while.
example[10]: The doctor told me to take some time off work and try to rest.
definition[6]: to gradually relax after you have been working hard or feeling anxious
example[11]: It had been a bad day and he just wanted to get home and unwind.
example[12]: Set in spectacular countryside, the Shiga Hotel is the perfect place to unwind.
definition[7]: to relax and not do very much, especially after working very hard or being ill
example[13]: Now that you’ve finished your exams, you can take it easy.
example[14]: The doctor said he’ll have to take things easy for while.
definition[8]: to rest for a short time after a tiring activity, especially by sitting with your feet resting on something
example[15]: Kate poured herself a drink and put her feet up.
example[16]: When you’re pregnant and doing a full-time job, you must find time to put your feet up.
definition[9]: to relax completely, or stop worrying and getting annoyed about things – used mainly by young people
example[17]: We spent the day chilling out by the pool.
example[18]: Hey dude, chill out! It’s only a car!
example[19]: It’s a great place to chill out.
example[20]: Let’s go back to my place and chill.
definition[10]: to become more relaxed and stop worrying about things
example[21]: I keep telling Mum that she needs to loosen up a bit.
example[22]: Tom had had a few drinks and was beginning to loosen up.
display[5]: put somebody at ease/make somebody feel at ease
definition[11]: to make someone feel relaxed, especially in a situation in which they might feel a little nervous
example[23]: A good interviewer will try to make you feel at ease.
example[24]: His friendly manner always puts people at their ease.
definition[12]: to make rules etc less strict
example[25]: The country decided to relax its rules on the foreign ownership of its airlines.
example[26]: Many employers are taking steps toward relaxed dress codes (=being allowed to dress informally at work) .
